title: Millionaire John Elliott explains why he's giving his business Ebac away | Metro News
text:
Jen Mills for Metro.co.uk Monday 27 Feb 2017 11:13 am John Elliot doesn’t want his company to be sold abroad (Picture: YouTube/RecognitionPR) 
A multi-millionaire has spoken out about why he decided to give his business away so it can always stay in the UK. 
John Elliott, 73, employs more than 200 people at his base near County Durham. 
Couple traumatised after hospital accidentally cremates baby In 2012, he announced he would not be passing on the business, Ebac, and £70m fortune to his children – and has now given an interview explaining why. 
Mr Elliott told the BBC this week: ‘I never felt it was mine to sell.’ 
‘We could make more money if we started to make our products in Poland,’ he added. ‘But, personally, I would rather make a smaller profit and assist the UK economy than make a bigger profit and devalue the UK economy.’ 
He set up a trust meaning the manufacturing company cannot be sold or moved abroad. It must keep all work in Newton Aycliffe, and surplus profits will be invested in community groups such as a local football team. His company built the first British washing machine in 40 years (Picture: Ebac) 
His company builds products including humidifiers and air conditioners. Ebac also designed and built the first British washing machine in 40 years. 
Parents promise to find out truth about death of two daughters in Vietnam Mr Elliott hit out at the political push for more and more people to go to university, saying his ‘biggest regret’ was leaving school at 15 – because he should have left at 13. 
‘The wrong idea was that we should make everyone in Britain very, very clever so we wouldn’t need to do any hard work,’ he told the BBC, saying that many people in the UK were happy doing work that does not require extensive qualifications. 
Describing his own workers, he claimed: ‘They are not very ambitious but they’re not second-class citizens, and there are a lot of them in the UK. He described his workers as ‘not second class citizens (Picture: YouTube/RecognitionPR) 
‘They are reasonably well motivated, but they’re at a low skill level.’ 
Mr Elliot has previously spoken out against a national minimum wage, saying it hinders business owners. 
He has also been outspoken in support of Brexit. More
